definition:
Let $T\colon V\to W$ be a linear mapping between vector spaces.

The set of all vectors in $V$ that $T$ maps to $0$ is called the
*kernel* (or *nullspace*) of $T$, and is denoted $\ker T$. So
$$\ker T = \{\, x \in V\mid T(x)=0\,\}.$$

The kernel is a vector subspace of $V$, and its is called the nullity of
$T$.

The function $T$ is injective if and only if $\ker T=\{0\}$ (see the ).
In particular, if the dimensions of $V$ and $W$ are equal and finite,
then $T$ is invertible if and only if $\ker T=\{0\}$.

If $U$ is a vector subspace of $V$, then we have
$$\ker T|_U = U \cap \ker T,$$ where $T|_U$ is the of $T$ to $U$.

When the linear mappings are given by means of matrices, the kernel of
the matrix $A$ is $$\ker A=\{\,x\in V \mid Ax=0\,\}.$$
